frameDefinitions: This frame concerns the infliction of punishment in return for a wrong suffered.

A Speaker talks about a Topic, which may be an action performed by the Speaker or an entity or state of affairs that they are associated with in order to suggest that the Speaker is worthy of admiration.
A Ratifier responds to a Proposal constructed by another party to make it binding over the Ratifier's jurisdiction or constituency.
An Agent pauses in the course of an Activity. ''
A Surrenderer is compelled to transfer a Theme to a Recipient.
In this frame, an Authority allows a Protagonist to know (in some way) that they may or may not engage in an Action.
frameExamples: (1) They took <t>revenge</t> for the deaths of two loyalist prisoners.
Turkish officials <t>boasted</t> of giving 'tens of thousands of dollars in surreptitious payments' to a prominent American politician.
The <t>ratification</t> of the Kyoto protocol has been a long, hard slog.
The government <t>froze</t> settlement construction in 1992 to facilitate peace talks.
Shortly after the boy <t>surrendered</t> the gun, the three remaining warriors made a rush for liberty.
The police officer <t>forbid</t> me from turning around .
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Avenger</fen> exacts revenge from the <fen>Offender</fen> for the <fen>Injury</fen>.
The <fen>Offender</fen> has committed the earlier <fen>Injury</fen> for which the <fen>Avenger</fen> seeks revenge.
The <fen>Avenger</fen> carries out a <fen>Punishment</fen> in order to exact revenge on the <fen>Offender</fen>.

The <fen>Injury</fen> is the injurious action committed by the <fen>Offender</fen> against the <fen>Injured_Party</fen>. This Frame Element need not always be realized, although it is conceptually necessary.

This frame element identifies the constituent that encodes who or what suffered the <fen>Injury</fen> at the hands of the <fen>Offender</fen>. Sometimes, an abstract concept such a person's honour or their blood is presented as the element that has suffered the <fen>Injury</fen>. These also constitute instances of  <fen>Injured_party</fen>
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the revenge occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the revenge occurs.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the person who produces a message about a <fen>Topic</fen>.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is a positively judged entity or state of affairs with which the <fen>Speaker</fen> is associated and about which they talk.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
A description of the state of affairs that redounds to the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s credit
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action that conveys the feeling of pride of the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The time when the statement is made.
The role specifies the place where the statement takes place.

The individual or body that confirms a Proposal negotiated or created by another party, causing it to become binding in a jurisdiction represented by the <fen>Ratifier</fen>.  In the case of direct democratic ratification, the jurisdiction and the <fen>Ratifier</fen> are the same.
The idea or course of action proposed by another individual or body which the <fen>Ratifier</fen> endorses and makes binding.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Ratifier</fen> makes the <fen>Proposal</fen> binding.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the <fen>Ratifier</fen> ratifies the <fen>Proposal</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Activity</fen> for which an <fen>Agent</fen> is pausing.
An <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> at which an <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where an <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
The person compelled to transfer the <fen>Theme</fen> to the <fen>Recipient</fen>.
The entity that ends up in possession of the <fen>Theme</fen>.
The object that changes possession.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Surrenderer</fen> gives the <fen>Theme</fen> to the <fen>Recipient</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Surrenderer</fen> gives the <fen>Theme</fen> to the <fen>Recipient</fen>.
The <fen>Authority</fen> orders the <fen>Protagonist</fen> to not engage in a particular <fen>Action</fen>.
The <fen>Protagonist</fen> wants to engage in an <fen>Action</fen>, but is ordered not to by the <fen>Authority</fen>.
The <fen>Action</fen> is what the <fen>Protagonist</fen> seeks to do, but is ordered not to.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the denying of permission occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the denial of permission occurs.
listRoleExamples: Jo had the affair as a kind of revenge <fex>against Pat</fex>.
The team took revenge <fex>with a resounding victory</fex>.
The team sought revenge <fex>for their 4-1 defeat last month</fex>.
During the 1990s <fex>Rio Grande Do Sul's governor, Olivio Dutra of the PT,</fex> PREENED about the province's GE-free status.
Mike Wallace was told that Canseco had bragged <fex>about steroids</fex>.
CNN's Jeff Greenfield bragged <fex>on the air</fex> recently that ratings are high.
Cosmai BRAGGED <fex>that Hyundai's latest quality rankings place the automaker on par with Honda and Toyota</fex>.
The senator's boastful <fex>exaggerations of her academic record at a New Hampshire campaign event</fex> also contributed to her withdrawal.

The public does not care, but the media definitely do as Haddock herself boasted
<fex>the next morning</fex> on Good Morning America.
'I'm Pat Crowe,' he boasted <fex>at the police station</fex>.
If <fex>we</fex> ratify Management 's plan , we 'll have to take a drug test every week !
President Aleksander Kwasniewski ratified <fex>protocols to the Europol Convention</fex>.
